text.p: Hewlett-Packard Co unveiled several new Internet technology partners and initiatives on Wednesday at an industry trade show here.

One initiative was a new architecture for images on the Internet based on a protocol jointly developed with Eastman Kodak and Live Picture. Hewlett said the Imaging for the Internet initiative was endorsed by Microsoft Corp, Informix Software Inc. and Oracle Corp..
Hewlett also announced plans to use Internet technology to connect customers and business partners.

It said it was working on interactive Web publishing and navigation products with Netscape Communications Corp. Over the past year, Hewlett has built an alliance with Netscape as a supplier of services to Netscape customers.

Palo Alto-based Hewlett also announced a strategic partnership with push technology startup PointCast, saying its HP-UX system is due to be the first Unix platform to support PointCast's I-Server for internal news publishing.

It also announced partnerships with NetScheme Solutions and Infospace for data access and management, and said a service to be available this summer will take advantage of Informix's Universal Server DataBlades.

In a deal with workstation rival Sun Microsystems Inc., Hewlett-Packard said it will provide an HP-UX edition of the Java Workshop, to accelerate development of Java applications for HP Domain servers and workstations.
HP said it will bundle Novell Inc.'s Novell Directory Services products, including LDAP, into its HP- UX system to provide global access to network services.

And latching onto one of the winter's hottest Internet startup companies, HP said it has entered a new strategic partnership with Marimba to work together on a scaleable method of distributing software updates to HP customers.
HP also said it was partnering with Gemplus and Informix to offer security- enhanced smart card products based on its HP Praesidium/ImagineCard security framework.
British Telecommunications said the card meets its requirements to develop new services based on authentication and digital signatures.

HP said Gemplus cards, smart card readers and an Informix-online Dynamic Server database will ship with its ImagineCard solutions. In the U.S. market, pricing for ImagineCard products will range from around $60 to $250 per user, depending on the number of installations. HP said it will begin shipping the products worldwide on April 1.
HP said its professional services organization will work with leading systems integrators, such as BSG and Cambridge Technology Partners to help customers utilize Internet technologies.

Hewlett's role as a supplier of technology to the market for internal corporate networks had drawn it into partnerships with leading-edge Internet technology companies, said executives at Hewlett, the nation's second-largest computer company.

The clustering of alliances was so broad that HP representatives had difficulty recognizing executives of some of its partners it was introducing to a crowded news briefing here at the Spring Internet World trade show. ((sam.perry@reuters.com, Palo Alto Bureau 415 846 5400))
